trial_identification.studytitle: Protein-bound uraemic toxins in Peritoneal Dialysis Patients
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Removal of selected low molecular weight highly protein-bound uraemic toxins in patients on peritoneal dialysis

interventions.interventions: Measurement of protein binding of small molecular weight toxins in peritoneal dialysis effluent assessed on 2 occasions 1 month apart Measurement is undertaken with an HPLC assay for simultaneous determination of 4 uraemic solutes:P Cresol,P Cresol Sulphate,Indoxyl Sulphate,3-indole-acteic acid based on methods described by Calaf et al:J Chromatogr B Analyt Technol Biomed Life Sci. 879(23):2281-2286.2011

primaryOutcome.outcome: The degree of protein binding for each of the measured solutes is established by measuring total solute in the PD effluent and then separating protein from the PD effluent and measuring the remaining free level. The difference is the bound solute which is expressed as a percentage of the total

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Bovine Serum albumin is added to the PD effluent at a range of concentrations likely to be achievable with wearable sorbent-based recycling PD. Total,bound and free solutes are measured.This enables the development of a binding curve related to protein concentrations

trial_design.statisticalmethods: The number to be studied, 30,although small, is large enough to cover the spectrum of protein excretion found in patients on PD. We do not expect a wide range of binding results

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Dept of Renal Medicine Auckland City Hospital Box 92024 Auckland 1023

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study looks at the protein binding of low molecular weight highly protein-bound toxins in Peritoneal Effuent of patients on Peritoneal Dialysis

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Ministry of Health No.1 The Terrace PO Box 5013 Wellington,6011
